title: Proverbs Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Proverbs chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Proverbs Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Proverbs Chapter 26.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:1, honour is not seemly for whom?
questions.correctAnswer: A fool
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:1 states that honour is not seemly for a fool, like snow in summer or rain in harvest.

questions.question: What comparison is used in Proverbs 26:2 to explain that a curse causeless shall not come?
options: As the lion in the street
As a stone in a sling
As a dog to its vomit
questions.correctAnswer: As the bird by wandering
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:2 compares a curse causeless to a bird by wandering and a swallow by flying, indicating it will not come without cause.

questions.question: What instrument is mentioned in Proverbs 26:3 for the fool's back?
questions.correctAnswer: A rod
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:3 mentions a rod for the fool's back, along with a whip for the horse and a bridle for the ass.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 26:4 advises to answer a fool according to his folly to avoid being like him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:4 actually advises not to answer a fool according to his folly, lest you be like him.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:5, why should one answer a fool according to his folly?
options: Lest he be wise in his own conceit
questions.correctAnswer: Lest he be wise in his own conceit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:5 instructs to answer a fool according to his folly to prevent him from thinking he is wise.

questions.question: What happens to one who sends a message by the hand of a fool, according to Proverbs 26:6?
options: He cutteth off the feet and drinketh damage
questions.correctAnswer: He cutteth off the feet and drinketh damage
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:6 warns that sending a message by a fool results in harm to oneself, described as cutting off feet and drinking damage.

questions.question: Complete the proverb from Proverbs 26:11: 'As a dog returneth to his _______, so a fool returneth to his folly.'
questions.correctAnswer: vomit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:11 uses the simile of a dog returning to its vomit to illustrate how a fool returns to his folly.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:12, who has more hope than a man wise in his own conceit?
questions.correctAnswer: A fool
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:12 states that there is more hope for a fool than for a man wise in his own conceit.

questions.question: What excuse does the slothful man give in Proverbs 26:13?
options: There is a lion in the way
questions.correctAnswer: There is a lion in the way
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:13 records the slothful man saying, 'There is a lion in the way,' to avoid work.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 26:14 compares the slothful to a door turning upon its hinges.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:14 makes this comparison to describe the slothful man.

questions.question: What does the slothful man hide in his bosom according to Proverbs 26:15?
questions.correctAnswer: His hand
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:15 says the slothful man hides his hand in his bosom because it grieveth him to bring it back to his mouth.

questions.question: Who is wiser in his own conceit than seven men that can render a reason, according to Proverbs 26:16?
questions.correctAnswer: The sluggard
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:16 states that the sluggard is wiser in his own conceit than seven men who can answer reason.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 26:20 says that where there is no talebearer, the strife ceaseth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:20 declares that without a talebearer, strife ends like a fire going out without wood.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:27, what happens to one who diggeth a pit?
questions.correctAnswer: He shall fall therein
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:27 warns that one who digs a pit will fall into it, a metaphor for consequences of evil deeds.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:28, what does a flattering mouth work?
questions.correctAnswer: Ruin
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:28 states that a flattering mouth works ruin, while a lying tongue hates those afflicted by it.

medium.title: Proverbs Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Proverbs Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with dealing patiently with a foolish person who keeps repeating their errors. Based on Proverbs 26, what biblical truth would you share about responding to fools?
options: Do not answer a fool according to his folly lest you become like him
Always correct a fool harshly to teach him a lesson
Ignore fools completely and refuse to speak to them
Praise a fool to keep peace
questions.correctAnswer: Do not answer a fool according to his folly lest you become like him
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:4 teaches that answering a fool according to his folly makes you like him. Verses 26:5 and 26:6 also emphasize the importance of wisdom in handling fools to avoid harm.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26 guide us in understanding the consequences of entrusting important tasks to unreliable people?
options: Sending a message by the hand of a fool leads to damage
It is wise to delegate to anyone available
Unreliable people can be trusted with important matters
questions.correctAnswer: Sending a message by the hand of a fool leads to damage
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:6 warns that sending a message through a fool leads to loss and harm. This teaches the importance of wisdom and discernment in delegation and stewardship (verses 26:3, 26:10).

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26, what is the biblical teaching about the nature of fools and their repeated behavior?
options: A fool returns to his folly like a dog returns to its vomit
Fools quickly learn from their mistakes
Fools are easily corrected by wise counsel
questions.correctAnswer: A fool returns to his folly like a dog returns to its vomit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:11 compares fools to dogs returning to vomit, illustrating their stubborn return to foolish behavior despite correction. This highlights the need for patience and prayer in witness and discipleship.

questions.question: What biblical principle about humility and self-awareness is taught in Proverbs 26 when it says, 'Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him'?
options: Prideful self-conceit is more dangerous than foolishness
Being wise in your own eyes is commendable
Fools have no hope at all
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful self-conceit is more dangerous than foolishness
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:12 warns that self-conceit blinds a person more than folly does. Humility and self-examination are essential virtues in Christian living (see also 26:24-26).

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26 counsel believers about handling conflicts that do not concern them?
options: Do not meddle in strife that does not belong to you
Always intervene to resolve every conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Do not meddle in strife that does not belong to you
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:17 compares meddling in others’ quarrels to grabbing a dog by the ears, which is dangerous and unwise. This teaches the importance of peace-making and discretion (see also 26:20-21).

questions.question: A believer struggles with bitterness and deceit in relationships. What does Proverbs 26 teach about the heart posture behind deceitful speech?
options: Deceit covers hatred and hides wickedness
Deceit is harmless if spoken gently
Fair speech always reflects a good heart
Deceit is a sign of humility
questions.correctAnswer: Deceit covers hatred and hides wickedness
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:24-26 teaches that hatred often disguises itself with deceitful lips, and wickedness will be revealed. This calls for honesty and integrity in speech and relationships.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 26 say about the work ethic and attitude of the slothful person?
options: The slothful finds excuses and is wiser in his own eyes
The slothful is diligent and hardworking
The slothful leads others by example
questions.correctAnswer: The slothful finds excuses and is wiser in his own eyes
questions.explanation: Verses 26:13-16 describe the slothful as fearful without cause, lazy, and self-deceived, highlighting the need for diligence and humility in stewardship and family life.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 26 teaches that honour is fitting and appropriate for a fool.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:1 compares honour given to a fool to snow in summer, indicating it is not appropriate. This teaches the importance of discerning whom we honor and respect.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 26 says that a lying tongue and a flattering mouth both bring harm and ruin.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:28 teaches that a lying tongue hates its victims and that flattering speech can cause ruin, showing the destructive power of dishonest communication.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; so is a __________ man to kindle strife.'
questions.correctAnswer: contentious
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:21 compares a contentious man to coals that kindle fire, illustrating how quarrelsome behavior fuels conflict rather than resolving it.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26 teach about the consequences of causing harm through gossip or talebearing?
options: Words of a talebearer are like wounds that reach deep
Gossip is harmless and promotes fellowship
Talebearing is a sign of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Words of a talebearer are like wounds that reach deep
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:22 explains that talebearing causes deep hurt, comparable to wounds reaching the innermost parts, warning believers to guard their speech carefully.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God's justice and reward is found in Proverbs 26 regarding fools and transgressors?
options: God rewards both fools and transgressors
God ignores fools and only rewards the righteous
Fools will never be held accountable
Transgressors are always forgiven without consequences
questions.correctAnswer: God rewards both fools and transgressors
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:10 states that God rewards fools and transgressors, reminding believers that God’s justice is comprehensive and that accountability is certain.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 26 teach about the dangers of meddling in conflicts and strife not belonging to us?
options: Meddling in others' strife is like grabbing a dog by the ears
It is wise to involve yourself in all disputes
questions.correctAnswer: Meddling in others' strife is like grabbing a dog by the ears
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:17 warns that interfering in unrelated conflicts is dangerous and unwise, teaching the value of discernment and peace-making.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26 illustrate the futility of slothfulness using a simile related to a door?
options: The slothful turns on his bed like a door on its hinges
The slothful is as steady as a closed door
The slothful opens opportunities like a door
The slothful is like a locked door
questions.correctAnswer: The slothful turns on his bed like a door on its hinges
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:14 compares the slothful to a door turning on its hinges, implying constant motion without progress, illustrating laziness and wasted effort.

questions.question: What practical wisdom about cause and effect does Proverbs 26 provide regarding those who plot harm against others?
options: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it
Plotting harm is a sign of strength
questions.correctAnswer: Whoever digs a pit will fall into it
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:27 teaches that those who scheme harm will suffer the consequences themselves, emphasizing God's justice and the principle of sowing and reaping.

hard.title: Proverbs Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Proverbs Chapter 26.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Proverbs 26:1 to describe the incongruity of honoring a fool?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:1 uses similes like 'As snow in summer, and as rain in harvest' to illustrate the inappropriateness of honoring a fool, highlighting sharp contrasts.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:2, what is the reason a curse will not come causelessly?
options: As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying
Due to the law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: As the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying
questions.explanation: The verse uses natural imagery 'as the bird by wandering, as the swallow by flying' to suggest that just as these birds follow their natural paths, curses do not come without cause.

questions.question: Proverbs 26:3 lists three items assigned to specific recipients. Which of the following is NOT one of those recipients?
questions.correctAnswer: King
questions.explanation: The verse assigns a whip to the horse, a bridle to the ass, and a rod to the fool, but does not mention a king.

questions.question: What is the paradox presented between Proverbs 26:4 and Proverbs 26:5 regarding responding to a fool?
options: Do not answer a fool according to his folly; answer him according to his folly
Ignore the fool completely; confront the fool directly
Use harsh words; use gentle words
Avoid the fool; engage in debate
questions.correctAnswer: Do not answer a fool according to his folly; answer him according to his folly
questions.explanation: These verses form a literary chiasm presenting two opposite instructions: 26:4 warns against responding in folly to avoid becoming like the fool, while 26:5 advises answering according to folly to prevent the fool from becoming conceited.

questions.question: In Proverbs 26:6, what metaphor illustrates the consequence of sending a message through a fool?
options: Cutting off the feet and drinking damage
Lighting a candle in the dark
questions.correctAnswer: Cutting off the feet and drinking damage
questions.explanation: The metaphor 'cutteth off the feet, and drinketh damage' illustrates self-inflicted harm by using a foolish messenger, emphasizing the risks of careless communication.

questions.question: Which verse uses the imagery of a dog returning to its vomit to describe fool's behavior?
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbs 26:11
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:11 explicitly states, 'As a dog returneth to his vomit, so a fool returneth to his folly,' portraying the repetitive nature of folly.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of the slothful man’s behavior described in Proverbs 26:13-15, considering ancient Near Eastern daily life?
options: Avoiding labor due to fear of wild animals
questions.correctAnswer: Exaggerating dangers to justify laziness
questions.explanation: The slothful man claims lions block the way and complains about effort, a reflection of laziness common enough to be proverbial in an agrarian society where daily labor was crucial.

questions.question: True or False: Proverbs 26:12 suggests that a man wise in his own conceit has more hope than a fool.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:12 states the opposite: 'there is more hope of a fool than of him' who is wise in his own conceit, highlighting the danger of self-deception.

questions.question: What analogy is used in Proverbs 26:17 to describe one who meddles in a strife not belonging to him?
options: Like one that taketh a dog by the ears
Like a lion roaring in the forest
Like a stone cast into a well
questions.correctAnswer: Like one that taketh a dog by the ears
questions.explanation: The analogy warns of the danger and foolishness of meddling in conflicts, likening it to grabbing a dog by the ears, which can lead to harm.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26:19 relate to the theme of deception and its social consequences?
options: It compares deceivers to mad men casting firebrands
It condemns those who refuse to speak
questions.correctAnswer: It compares deceivers to mad men casting firebrands
questions.explanation: Verse 19 compares deceivers who downplay their harmful acts to mad men throwing dangerous weapons, linking deception with chaos and social harm.

questions.question: Which verse in Proverbs 26 uses the metaphor of burning coals to describe a contentious person?
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbs 26:21
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:21 states: 'As coals are to burning coals, and wood to fire; so is a contentious man to kindle strife,' emphasizing how contentious people increase conflict.

questions.question: In Proverbs 26:23-25, what literary technique is used to describe a person whose lips are 'burning' but whose heart is wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor and irony
questions.explanation: The person is metaphorically likened to a 'potsherd covered with silver dross'—something superficially attractive but worthless underneath, creating ironic contrast.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Proverbs 26:27 says, 'Whoso diggeth a pit shall ______ therein: and he that rolleth a stone, it will return upon him.'
questions.correctAnswer: fall
questions.explanation: The verse warns that harmful intentions often backfire on the doer, using the imagery of digging a pit and falling into it.

questions.question: What is the theological implication of Proverbs 26:10 stating that 'The great God that formed all things both rewardeth the fool, and rewardeth transgressors'?
options: God's justice is impartial and comprehensive
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice is impartial and comprehensive
questions.explanation: This verse implies God's sovereignty encompasses all people, rewarding even fools and transgressors, indicating a complex divine justice beyond human understanding.

questions.question: Which verse highlights the danger of a lying tongue and a flattering mouth?
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbs 26:28
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:28 states, 'A lying tongue hateth those that are afflicted by it; and a flattering mouth worketh ruin,' emphasizing the social destructiveness of deceit.

theological.title: Proverbs Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Proverbs Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:1, how is honour described when it is given to a fool?
questions.correctAnswer: As snow in summer
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:1 states that honour is not seemly for a fool, comparing it to snow in summer and rain in harvest, both untimely and inappropriate. Similarly, Job 34:18 notes God's disdain for folly, and in the New Testament, 1 Corinthians 1:27 highlights God choosing the foolish to shame the wise, showing that human honour misplaced on folly is improper.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 26:3 prescribe as a punishment or correction for a fool?
options: A rod for the fool's back
questions.correctAnswer: A rod for the fool's back
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:3 directly mentions a rod for the fool's back, symbolizing discipline. This aligns with Proverbs 13:24 on the importance of correction, Hebrews 12:6 on God's discipline for His children, and Revelation 3:19 which speaks of Jesus chastening those He loves, highlighting divine correction of folly.

questions.question: What warning is given about answering a fool according to his folly in Proverbs 26:4?
questions.correctAnswer: You may become like him
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:4 warns that answering a fool according to his folly risks becoming like him. This echoes Ecclesiastes 7:7 on the fool's annoyance, Matthew 7:6 about not giving what is holy to dogs (fools), and James 1:19 urging quick listening but slow speaking, emphasizing cautious engagement with folly.

questions.question: Proverbs 26:5 advises to answer a fool according to his folly for what reason?
options: Lest he be wise in his own conceit
questions.correctAnswer: Lest he be wise in his own conceit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:5 counsels answering a fool according to his folly to prevent him from becoming wise in his own eyes. This aligns with 1 Corinthians 4:10 where apostles are called 'fools for Christ', and Romans 12:16 urging not to be wise in your own sight, highlighting the danger of self-deception.

questions.question: What simile does Proverbs 26:11 use to describe a fool returning to his folly?
options: As a dog returneth to his vomit
As a bird returns to its nest
As a lion returns to the hunt
As a serpent sheds its skin
questions.correctAnswer: As a dog returneth to his vomit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:11 compares a fool returning to folly to a dog returning to vomit, illustrating repeated sinfulness. This is consistent with 2 Peter 2:22 referencing the same image, Romans 6:1 warning against continuing in sin, and Hebrews 10:26 cautioning about deliberate sin after receiving knowledge of truth.

questions.question: According to Proverbs 26:12, who has less hope than a fool?
options: A man wise in his own conceit
questions.correctAnswer: A man wise in his own conceit
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:12 states there is more hope for a fool than for a man wise in his own eyes, highlighting the danger of self-conceit. This theme appears in Isaiah 5:21 warning against being wise in one's own eyes, Romans 12:16 urging humility, and James 4:6 emphasizing God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26:13 describe the slothful man's excuse for not working?
options: There is a lion in the way
questions.correctAnswer: There is a lion in the way
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:13 portrays the slothful man making excuses by saying there is a lion in the way, symbolizing fear or avoidance. This matches Ecclesiastes 10:18 on laziness causing decay, Matthew 25:26-30 on the unfaithful servant, and 2 Thessalonians 3:10 affirming that those unwilling to work should not eat.

questions.question: What is the comparison used in Proverbs 26:17 for one who meddles in strife not belonging to him?
options: Like one that taketh a dog by the ears
Like one who builds on sand
Like one who chases the wind
Like one who carries fire in his hand
questions.correctAnswer: Like one that taketh a dog by the ears
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:17 compares a meddler in strife to one grabbing a dog by its ears, emphasizing danger and folly. This correlates with Galatians 5:15 warning that biting and devouring each other harms the community, and 1 Timothy 5:13 cautioning against becoming busybodies, reflecting the wisdom of avoiding unnecessary conflict.

questions.question: Which divine attribute is emphasized in Proverbs 26:10 regarding God's treatment of fools and transgressors?
options: God rewards both the fool and the transgressor
God punishes fools but rewards the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: God rewards both the fool and the transgressor
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:10 states that the great God rewards both the fool and transgressors, reflecting God's justice and sovereignty over all. This is consistent with Ecclesiastes 8:11 on delayed judgment, Romans 1:18-20 showing God's patience, and Matthew 5:45 describing God's sun rising on the evil and good, revealing His impartial nature.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 26:20 say will happen where there is no talebearer?
questions.correctAnswer: Strife ceaseth
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:20 teaches that where there is no talebearer (gossip), strife will cease, highlighting the destructive power of slander. This is affirmed in James 3:5-6 on the power of the tongue, Ephesians 4:31-32 urging kindness and forgiveness, and Psalm 34:13 advocating guarding the tongue for peace.

questions.question: Which metaphor does Proverbs 26:22 use to describe the effect of the words of a talebearer?
options: As wounds going deep into the belly
As honey sweet to the soul
As a shield protecting from harm
questions.correctAnswer: As wounds going deep into the belly
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:22 compares the words of a talebearer to wounds that penetrate deeply, symbolizing harmful gossip. This aligns with Proverbs 18:21 on the power of life and death in the tongue, James 3:8 about the tongue's potential for evil, and Matthew 12:36 warning about accountability for careless words.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 26:27 warn about those who dig a pit or roll a stone?
options: They will fall into it or it will return upon them
They will build a foundation for others
They will be honored by the community
questions.correctAnswer: They will fall into it or it will return upon them
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:27 warns that those who plot evil (dig a pit) will suffer its consequences themselves, reflecting the principle of sowing and reaping. This principle is also taught in Galatians 6:7, Job 4:8, and Matthew 7:12, reinforcing divine justice and moral accountability.

questions.question: How does Proverbs 26:28 describe the impact of a lying tongue and a flattering mouth?
options: A lying tongue hates those afflicted by it, and a flattering mouth works ruin
A lying tongue brings peace, and a flattering mouth brings joy
A lying tongue is easily forgiven, and a flattering mouth is welcomed
A lying tongue is harmless, and a flattering mouth is sincere
questions.correctAnswer: A lying tongue hates those afflicted by it, and a flattering mouth works ruin
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:28 highlights the destructive nature of lying and flattery, emphasizing deceit harms relationships. This is consistent with Psalm 101:7 condemning deceitful tongues, Colossians 3:9 urging no lying to one another, and Luke 6:45 teaching that the mouth reflects the heart's fullness.

questions.question: In Proverbs 26:23, what is likened to burning lips and a wicked heart?
options: A potsherd covered with silver dross
A lion roaring in the night
questions.correctAnswer: A potsherd covered with silver dross
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:23 compares burning lips and a wicked heart to a potsherd covered with silver dross, symbolizing something outwardly attractive but inwardly worthless or corrupt. This resembles Isaiah 64:6 on filthy rags, Matthew 23:27 criticizing the Pharisees as whitewashed tombs, and 1 Samuel 16:7 teaching that God looks at the heart, not outward appearance.

questions.question: What does Proverbs 26:25 advise regarding someone who speaks fair but hides deceit?
questions.correctAnswer: Believe them not
questions.explanation: Proverbs 26:25 warns not to believe someone who speaks fair but harbors evil in their heart, signifying hypocrisy. This teaching parallels Matthew 7:15 on false prophets, Jeremiah 9:8 condemning deceptive lips, and 2 Corinthians 11:13 warning about deceitful workers, emphasizing discernment.
